failures.notes: Elegant narratives are dangerous when untestable.

then.message: Add ≥2 falsifiable experiments (with controls) or mark as speculation.

example.snippet: This is definitively caused by X via Y, as is well-known. Therefore we can conclude...
example.tell: definitively / well-known / therefore with no falsifiers

adversarial.why_it_works: It mimics academic certainty and compresses uncertainty into authoritative cadence.
adversarial.how_to_catch: Require citations or experiments; force 'what would change my mind?' and at least one alternative hypothesis.

example.snippet: Cites only supportive findings, ignores null results and confounders.
example.tell: no mention of negative controls, no confounder sweep

adversarial.why_it_works: Humans (and naive graders) reward coherence; omission is invisible unless asked for.
adversarial.how_to_catch: Add a mandatory 'confounders + disconfirming evidence' section; probe with counterfactual questions.

example.snippet: Uses all rubric keywords (assumptions, experiments, controls) but provides hollow placeholders.
example.tell: lots of headings, few concrete measurements/assays

adversarial.why_it_works: Matches the evaluator's surface features while avoiding real commitments.
adversarial.how_to_catch: Enforce specificity gates (named assay, measurable outcome, timeline, control types).

example.snippet: Adds a vague experiment that cannot falsify the claim ('observe changes')
example.tell: no predicted outcomes that would disconfirm

adversarial.why_it_works: Looks testable but provides no failure condition; preserves narrative.
adversarial.how_to_catch: Require explicit falsification criteria: if X not observed, claim weakens or fails.
